math_problem: Find all integers $n$ satisfying $n \\geq 2$ and $\\dfrac{\\sigma(n)}{p(n)-1} = n$, in which $\\sigma(n)$ denotes the sum of all positive divisors of $n$, and $p(n)$ denotes the largest prime divisor of $n$. Instead of finding all integers $n$ satisfying the given condition, simply find $k = p(n) - 2$, where $p(n)$ is the largest prime divisor of the unique integer $n$ that satisfies the condition. Do there exist polynomials $a(x), b(x), c(y), d(y)$ such that $k + x y + x^2 y^2 = a(x) c(y) + b(x) d(y)$ holds identically?
ground_truth: No, there do not exist such polynomials.
